title: Study Team
text: The CoMP-MRS project is lead by an international consortium of collaborators who have research interests in preclinical MRS.

title: Data
text:
Data storage

Short-term data storage on OneDrive to transfer data
To gain access to OneDrive for data upload, each investigator should first provide details of their data packet(s) by filling in the first available row in the study spreadsheet. Once the spreadsheet is filled out, investigators will be assigned a OneDrive folder for each data packet to be submitted, numbered according to their corresponding row in the study spreadsheet (DP01, DP02, etc.). During submission time, OneDrive folders will be editable only by the lead investigators (JN & CC) and the submitting investigators to avoid accidental cross-contamination between investigator data packet folders.


Mid- and long-term data storage
In the mid-term, following the initial data submission phase, data will be stored at EPFL/SRI on high-performance computing servers. In the long term, data storage will move to OpenNeuro, a publicly available repository, when the first preprint is submitted.

title: Data
text:
Data processing
Data will be preprocessed using FID-A and Osprey, both MATLAB-based software. A basic processing pipeline will be established, consisting of 1) coil combination, if applicable; 2) iterative retrospective frequency drift correction, if possible; 3) averaging; 4) measurement of SNR; 5) measurement of linewidth; and 6) visual inspection for artifacts. Processing scripts and visual quality inspection procedures specific to this study will be shared publicly on the CoMP-MRS GitHub repository.
For each provided scan, we will attempt to generate a mask of the VOI position in a standard space. This will be achieved by 1) generating a mask of the voxel position in the provided structural space; 2) registering the provided structural MRI scan with the standard rat or mouse brain template; and 3) transforming the VOI mask from the structural space into the standard template space. For the rat brain, standard space will consist of the Fischer 344 MRI-derived atlas of Goerzen et al. (2020)1. For the mouse brain, standard space will consist of the Dorr/DSURQE mouse brain MRI template.
Spectral analysis will be performed in Osprey using a basis set that consists of a fixed list of metabolites and macromolecule peaks. Metabolite and macromolecule basis sets will be generated by JN/CC, and will be made available at the end of the study.
For a detailed procedure, see Analysis.

title: Collaborative Multi-Center Preclinical MRS Study (CoMP-MRS)
text:
Summary
In this international collaborative project, we seek to gather the rodent (rat and mouse) MRS community toward performing a multi-center comparison of 1H MRS techniques with the overriding goal of developing and establishing guidelines for best methodological practices in preclinical MRS research. Inspired by the multi-site fMRI study of the rat brain led by Joanes Grandjean1, we want to examine the distribution of neurochemical concentrations and spectral quality measures at the population level within the healthy rodent brain across sites, as well as establish best practices for preclinical MRS methods.
To do so, we will gather a “retrospective dataset” of short-echo time (TE) rodent brain MRS data from individual labs (n = 8 rats/mice per lab, any protocol, volume of interest in either hippocampus or striatum). Going further, we will seek to obtain additional datasets pertaining to within-lab test-retest assessment (i.e., scans that were collected in the same control animals within a period of 6 months or less). Finally, we would like to organize a standardized data collection arm of this study for labs interested (a “prospective dataset”). This would include the de novo acquisition of a dataset (n = 8) using predefined, mutually-agreed, and standardized parameters consistent across all participating labs.
The overall objective of this work is to establish an openly available repository of rodent brain MRS data for researchers, to publish an extensive description of the collective dataset in a peer-reviewed journal, and provide a “standardized” protocol for rat and mouse brain MRS that will enable the acquisition of reproducible and reliable MRS datasets.

title: Collaborative Multi-Center Preclinical MRS Study (CoMP-MRS)
text:
Goals

To provide a large rat/mouse 1H MRS collective dataset at short TE
To describe reference population data parameter distributions (e.g., SNR, linewidth, signal model fit error, metabolite concentrations, etc.)
To provide evidence-based recommendations for 1H MRS acquisitions in two brain regions (hippocampus and striatum) of rats and mice
To provide standardized processing and quantification steps/tools that can be performed with available software options
To foster collaborations and discussion across the preclinical MRS community by enabling close communications among researchers
To demonstrate test-retest reliability of preclinical MRS data
To determine whether the reproducibility/variability of neurochemical concentration estimates is improved when all data are collected using a standardized protocol (2nd data submission) compared to when the data were not standardized (1st data submission)
To investigate the human-factor variability during data acquisition using a standardized protocol
To organize an international seminar on 1H MRS data standardization of the rodent brain at EPFL
To make all data, processing scripts, and analysis scripts openly available to the community via an online repository (e.g., OpenNeuro, GitHub, etc.)
